Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) will study the combined effects of self-generated wave dynamics and local Coulomb collisional dynamics on electrons in the solar wind, while focusing on local acceleration of electrons to suprathermal velocities by self-generated enhanced electrostatic fluctuations. The PI's objective is to determine the physical origin of the so-called 'kappa' velocity distribution function (VDF) associated with the solar wind electrons. Since this task has not been attempted before, the PI expects these results to shed light on electron dynamics in the solar wind, and to help experimenters in interpreting their existing data.

The PI notes that the turbulent and nonlinear plasma processes to be studied here affect charged particle acceleration in many different laboratory and astrophysical environments, and that this effort will therefore have wider interdisciplinary impact. The PI's numerical results will be shared with the community through workshops and publications. This project will also contribute to the education and training of a young postdoctoral scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research project the PI investigated naturally occurring phenomena that take place in the empty between the Sun and the Earth's upper atmosphere. Many non scientists think that the outer space is empty and vacuous, but actually it is full of electrons, protons, and electromagnetic radiation, except that the concentration is so low that they cannot be seen with naked eyes. However, with the aid of scientific instruments one may detect various physical activies. The reason this problemhas practical significance is because the Earth is strongly influenced by the Sun's activity, especially the near-Earth space where artificial satellites operate. Before the advent of modern age, the Sun's harmful effect on the Earth was of little concern to humans since the Earth is protected by a magnetic bubble, called the magnetosphere. The only visible sign that the Sun is affecting the Earth was Northern Lights. However, in modern age of artificial satellites, it is crucial to understand how the Sun's activity influences the Earth's environement. This is because tese satellites are sensitive to radiation from the Sun, so scientific community aims to make predictions ahead of time, if and when the activity that starts from the Sun may reach the Earth orbit, so that sensitive intruments onboard the spacecraft may be turned off and so forth. Such an effort is contemporarily known as the space weather forecasting, which contrasts to the usual weather forecasting on Earth's surface. Space weather forecasting is in early stage when compared with the usual weather forecasting. This is because the space so vast, and detection with artificial satellites and/or ground-based instruments are difficult. In order for such an effort to succeed, scientists must combine satellite technology as well as theoretical modeling effort. Theoretical modeling requires deep understanding of underlying physics associated with the space environement. Many physical processes must be understood on the basis of sophisticated mathematical models. The PI's expertise is on theoretical modeling. He developed sophisticated mathematical models that explain and predict how electrons, protons, and electromagnetic radiation emanating from the Sun behave as they approach the near-Earth space.

Among Yoon's discoveries is that the space environment is not like the Earth's environment in many respects. For one, on Earth, we experience that if we mix hot and cold waters, after some time, they reach thermal equilibrium - that is, the water becomes lukewarm. This is just an example of thermodynamic, especially the second law of thermodynamics. The reason why hot and cold waters mix is because water molecules collide and exchange their kinetic energy at the miscroscopic level. In space, because the medium is so rare protons and electrons rarely ever collide with each other or among themselves so that mixing of temperatures, as in the example of hot and cold water, cannot take place. Instead, they exchange their energy by repelling and pulling each other just so slightly as a result of long-ranged electromagnetic force. An indirect consequence of such a process had been known since the 1960s when the space exploration began. The evidence comes from measuring the collection of many, many electrons and analyzing how they are distributed. By comparing the distribution of electrons measured in space versus those that can be found on Earth, scientists were able to detect the telltale sign that the outer space behaved differently from Earth. However, such findings were never satisfactorily explained by mathematical model. The PI developed a mathematical theory to explain this, however, and when his model is compared against actual electron distribution measured in space, an excellent agreement was found, thus proving that the PI's model is reliable. The reason is discovery is important is because the PI may apply the same mathematical model to explain not just the electrons, but a whole array of other phenomena that take place in empty between the Sun and the Earth. In short, the PI's research accomplishment may have laid a firm theoretical foundation for future space weather forecasting program.
